bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: Walt Whitman to Richard Maurice Bucke, 16 June 1891
bibl.orgName: The Charles E. Feinberg Collection of the Papers of Walt Whitman, 1839–1919, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.
bibl.note: Whitman wrote this letter to Bucke on the back of the final page of a letter he had received from William H. Taylor on June 15, 1891. Whitman enclosed Taylor's full letter for Bucke to read.

revisionDesc.change: Second check: corrected and added notes, added DOI, corrected transcription and encoding
transcribed, encoded; SLIS:6335: Metadata Theories and Applications Class, Fall 2020, Micah Bateman, Lecturer, University of Iowa

body.p: The great matter here is the hot wave, continued, but a palpable breeze to-day—Even at that it's the hottest weather ever known here with the same or worse prospect ahead—I am standing pretty well thus far now just after noon—got along fairly last night—bowel movement yesterday—Horace here evn'g—Stoddart will publish the report with some short cutting—Made my b'kfast on some nice stew'd cherries & brown bread—this letter is f'm an old Broadway omnibus driver NY chum—F'm 25 to 45 I c'd hop on & get up front a stage while going a good trot—also put my hand on a six barr'd fence & leap over at once—(terrible reminissance now)—
